title: Manchester United chief Ed Woodward keen to smooth out relationship with arch critic Gary Neville
text:
Manchester United chief Ed Woodward wants to patch up his relationship with arch critic Gary Neville for the good of the club.

Woodward and the influential former United captain haven’t spoken for five months with Neville increasingly strident on television in blaming the executive vice-chairman for the slump in form at Old Trafford.

Ironically, United have made the relationship with academy players and former stars a central plank of their philosophy under Ole Gunnar Solskjaer but are aware the strategy is weakened if there are difficulties with the “leader” of Sir Alex Ferguson’s Class of 92.

Ed Woodward is said to be keen to smooth out his relationship with Sky Sports' Gary Neville

Neville has been a strong critic of the Man United chief executive in his role as a pundit

The relationship between Neville and club was further strained by his purchase of Hotel Football next to Old Trafford.

It’s understood former manager Jose Mourinho didn’t want the United squad to stay there before home games but his departure has offered a fresh opportunity for a new partnership and United are expected to approach Neville to try and bury the hatchet.

Neville, whose 601 appearances for United places him fifth in the all-time list, has developed into one of the most powerful men in football since retirement, combining successful careers in broadcast and business.

Woodward has become one of his most regular targets as United have struggled to stay at the top since Sir Alex Ferguson retired in 2013.

Last month, Neville called on Woodward to stop having any influence over transfers, saying: ‘I don’t believe the guy at the top should be there doing it any more, I think he has had his chance.’

Neville blamed Woodward for Jose Mourinho's sour end to his tenure at the club

And in 2018 during the final stages of Mourinho’s tenure, the former defender claimed; ‘It’s not the manager (to blame), it’s the lack of football leadership above him. They are bouncing all over the place with no plan.’

Since then, Woodward has altered the football structure of the club and signed Harry Maguire, Aaron wan-Bissaka and Daniel James.

He’s also reached out to the Class of 92 with Nicky Butt working at the club, but has been estranged from Neville.

Keen to utilise former United stars in the same way that Liverpool have done, Ferguson favourites Darren Fletcher and Patrice Evra have been invited to the training ground at Carrington.

Woodward would like to employ a former big-name player to work as a media ambassador and talk to British and overseas media to reflect the club’s standpoint.

authors: Joe Bernstein For Mail On Sunday
